Award.AwardTitle: A Proposal to Provide Leadership Development and Technical Assistance to TCUP Faculty and Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
To enhance the quality of STEM programs at TCUP institutions, QEM will design and conduct two workshops for TCUP project staff, in Years One and Two respectively: Strategic Planning Within/Sustaining Enhancements Beyond TCUP-supported Projects and Financial Management Within TCUP Projects. To increase the participation/quality of preparation of Native individuals in STEM careers, QEM will design and conduct two professional development workshops to support STEM faculty at TCUP institutions: The Fundamentals of Education Research and Assessment and Evaluation of TCUP-supported STEM Instructional Strategies (in Years One and Two respectively).

QEM will continue a Faculty Fellowship initiative that supports the six-month placement each year at NSF of a STEM faculty member from a TCUP-supported institution to provide the Fellow with exposure to, and immersion in, the Foundation?s programs, policies, and procedures. This initiative provides NSF program directors and staff the opportunity to interact directly with and gain insight from a TCUP faculty member. QEM will to continue offering, in each of the three years, ten-week summer internships at QEM for five STEM students from TCUP institutions. The TCUP Internship program is focused on activities and experiences that encourage the participating students to persist in STEM.

Intellectual Merit. In implementing this project, QEM will utilize/build on experience gained, through prior TCUP support, in working with faculty, staff, administrators, and students at TCUs. The project?s faculty-focused workshops will advance participants? knowledge and understanding of STEM education research methodologies as well as of assessment and evaluation of the effectiveness of STEM pedagogical strategies, while workshops for TCUP project staff will strengthen their strategic planning and management skills to benefit both current and future STEM initiatives. The Faculty Fellowships and Student Internships will continue to offer the reciprocal benefits of new experiences and shared/diverse perspectives for the Fellows, interns, and NSF Program Directors and staff. The project will be enriched by the advice and counsel of an External Advisory Committee composed of Tribal College leaders and others with first-hand knowledge and experience working with Tribal Colleges.

Broader Impacts. The Project?s initiatives will impact the way that STEM is taught at TCUP institutions; enable faculty to gauge the effectiveness of their approaches to STEM teaching; increase familiarity with other NSF funding opportunities as well as with the Foundation?s proposal review process; increase the project staff?s understanding of strategic planning and sustainability strategies as well as of effective financial management and increase student understanding of/interest in pursuing STEM careers. Workshop information, registration and presentations; information on the faculty fellowship/internship opportunities; and other project-related information will be available at QEM?s website to ensure broader dissemination of this information beyond email communication with STEM faculty and project staff.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Between 2014 and 2020,with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Award #1313529, the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Networkconducted a series of professional development meetings that supported over 120 STEM faculty, administrators and researchers atTribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) grantee institutions.

The goals of this award were to: 1) enhance the quality of STEM programs at TCUP grantee institutions; and 2) increase the participation and retention of Native Americans, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians in STEM careers by providing leadership and professional development for their faculty, staff, and students. The project planned and conducted six events, a brief description of the meetings is provided below.

Strategic Planning Workshop: In March 2014, QEM hosted a professional development workshop,Strategic Planning within/Sustaining Enhancements beyond TCUP-supported projects.The meeting discussed ways for TCUP PIs to maintain project activities beyond the funding period by utilizing existing infrastructure and resources at their institutions with STEM faculty at TCUP grantee institutions.Nineteen (19) STEM faculty/staff from ten TCUP grantee institutions attended the workshop.

Education Research Workshop: In October, 2014, QEM hosted a professional development workshop,Fundamentals of Education Research for Faculty at Tribal Colleges and Universities.The workshop focused on key topical areas includingimportance of education research at Tribal Colleges, research design and methodologies for educational research,cultural competency in STEM education research, andoverview of TCUP-supported education research funding opportunities.Thirteen (13) STEM and Education Research faculty from seven (7) TCUP grantee institutions attended the workshop.

Financial Management Workshop: In December, 2014, QEM hosted a professional development workshop,Financial Management for the National Science Foundation (NSF)'s Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) Grantees.Thirteen (13) TCUP PIs and Finance/Business Office staff from seven (7) TCUP grantee institutions attended the workshop.At the workshop, participantsdiscussed specific concerns they had regarding thefinancialmanagementof theirTCUPawards and received advice to address their concerns.

Assessment and Evaluation Workshop. In October, 2015, QEM conducted a professional development workshop, onAssessment and Evaluation of STEM Instructional Practices at TCUP-supported Institutions. At the workshop, institutional teams drafted outline plans for the assessment and evaluation of STEM instructional practices on their campuses.Twenty-six STEM faculty representing teams from ten TCUP grantee institutions attended the workshop.

Leadership Development Institute (LDI):In October, 2017, QEM conducted theTCUP LDI forEarly Career Facultyat NSF TCUP Grantee Institutions. The purpose of the QEM/TCUP Leadership Institute was to engage and support Alaska Native, Native American, and Native Hawaiian early career faculty at TCUP institutions in developing their academic leadership and career planning skills to enable them to serve as leaders at their institutions. Twenty-one (21) faculty participated in the institute.

TCUP STEM Strategic Planning Symposium: In July, 2020,QEM convened a symposium to help participants from TCUP institutionshone their skills for using strategic planning to advance external support for STEM programs atTCUPinstitutions.Thirty (30) senior administrators/research faculty from TCUP grantee institutions attended the two-day Symposium. Sixteen (16) TCUP institutions were represented at the symposium.

Over the TCUP project grant period, QEM has supported 122 STEM faculty/researchers at TCUs through this grant (Table 1).
